name: Adam Shostack
background: Threat modeling expert, former Microsoft security architect. Wrote 'Threat Modeling: Designing for Security'. Created STRIDE methodology. Focuses on making threat modeling practical.

principles.name: STRIDE threat categorization
principles.description: Categorize threats as Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information disclosure, Denial of service, Elevation of privilege. Systematic categories prevent overlooking threat classes.
principles.falsification: When STRIDE categories miss domain-specific threats or create false sense of completeness

principles.name: Threat model early and often
principles.description: Threat modeling at design time is cheaper than fixing vulnerabilities in production. Make it part of development process, not a one-time audit. Iterate as design evolves.
principles.falsification: When rapid iteration makes early threat modeling impractical or wasteful

principles.name: Use diagrams to find threats
principles.description: Data flow diagrams reveal where trust boundaries are crossed. Visual representation makes threats visible to non-experts. Draw the system, then attack the drawing.
principles.falsification: When system complexity makes diagrams misleading simplifications
